evidence: Today's lecture will cover the Fourier transform, which is a key concept in signal processing and medical imaging.
We'll explore the Fourier transform properties and their practical applications in signal processing and imaging.
We'll extend our thinking to higher dimensions, showing how the Fourier transform applies to images and beyond.
By the end of this lecture, you should understand the mathematical structure of the Fourier transform and its real-world value in medical imaging.

concepts.raw:
{"slide_id": "Slide9", "model": "Qwen/Qwen2-VL-7B-Instruct", "prompt": "concepts", "timestamp_utc": "2025-11-08T23:23:35.958839+00:00", "text_length": 1555, "raw_output": "system
You are a helpful AI for medical imaging.
user
System:
You are an expert educator in medical imaging. From the following slide text,
extract the key technical or scientific concepts that are essential for understanding the topic.

User:
SLIDE_TEXT:
So now that we’ve covered the Fourier series — and we’ve seen why changing representations can make problems easier — it’s time to dive into the main topic of today’s lecture: the Fourier transform.

This corresponds to Chapter 4 in the book draft I shared with you. I do plan to revise it soon — polish up some explanations and fix a few typos — and I’ll send you the updated version once it’s ready.

Here’s how we’ll structure today’s lecture:
First, in Section 1, we’ll talk about how the Fourier transform is derived from the Fourier series. This transition is logical and elegant, and it gives us a solid foundation for everything that follows.

Then, in Section 2, we’ll explore some of the most important properties of the Fourier transform. These properties aren’t just mathematical curiosities — they’re practical tools used in signal processing, imaging, and many other fields.

After that, in Section 3, we’ll extend our thinking to higher dimensions. I’ll show you how the Fourier transform applies not just to one-dimensional signals, but also to images — and beyond. I’ll even walk you through an example where converting an image to the Fourier domain makes it easy to remove noise.

Finally, in Section 4, we’ll wrap things up with a few remarks and reflections.

So by the end of this lecture, you should not only understand the mathematical structure of the Fourier transform, but also see its real-world value, especially in areas like medical imaging.
Let’s get started with the first section: the derivation of the Fourier transform.

STRICT INSTRUCTIONS:
- Return pure JSON only. No prose, no markdown, no code fences.
- Each concept must appear verbatim (case-insensitive) in SLIDE_TEXT.
- Assign exactly one category from:
  software | workflow | mathematics | signal_processing | frequency_domain |
  physics | instrumentation | data_processing | reconstruction |
  quality_metric | communication | modality | anatomy | algorithm | ai_ml
- Reject filler or administrative text.
- Output format:
{
  "concepts": [
    {"term": "<exact term from slide>", "category": "<category>"}
  ],
  "evidence": ["<short supporting phrase from SLIDE_TEXT>"]
}

assistant
{
  "concepts": [
    {"term": "Fourier transform", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "Fourier series", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "Fourier transform derivation", "category": "mathematics"},
    {"term": "Fourier transform properties", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "High-dimensional Extension", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "Fourier domain", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "signal processing", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "medical imaging", "category": "modality"}
  ],
  "evidence": [
    "Today’s lecture will cover the Fourier transform, which is a key concept in signal processing and medical imaging.",
    "We’ll explore the Fourier transform properties and their practical applications in signal processing and imaging.",
    "We’ll extend our thinking to higher dimensions, showing how the Fourier transform applies to images and beyond.",
    "By the end of this lecture, you should understand the mathematical structure of the Fourier transform and its real-world value in medical imaging."
  ]
}", "parsed": {"concepts": [{"term": "Fourier transform", "category": "signal_processing"}, {"term": "Fourier series", "category": "signal_processing"}, {"term": "Fourier domain", "category": "signal_processing"}, {"term": "signal processing", "category": "signal_processing"}, {"term": "medical imaging", "category": "modality"}], "evidence": ["Today's lecture will cover the Fourier transform, which is a key concept in signal processing and medical imaging.", "We'll explore the Fourier transform properties and their practical applications in signal processing and imaging.", "We'll extend our thinking to higher dimensions, showing how the Fourier transform applies to images and beyond.", "By the end of this lecture, you should understand the mathematical structure of the Fourier transform and its real-world value in medical imaging."]}}

User:
SLIDE_TEXT:
So now that we’ve covered the Fourier series — and we’ve seen why changing representations can make problems easier — it’s time to dive into the main topic of today’s lecture: the Fourier transform.

This corresponds to Chapter 4 in the book draft I shared with you. I do plan to revise it soon — polish up some explanations and fix a few typos — and I’ll send you the updated version once it’s ready.

Here’s how we’ll structure today’s lecture:
First, in Section 1, we’ll talk about how the Fourier transform is derived from the Fourier series. This transition is logical and elegant, and it gives us a solid foundation for everything that follows.

Then, in Section 2, we’ll explore some of the most important properties of the Fourier transform. These properties aren’t just mathematical curiosities — they’re practical tools used in signal processing, imaging, and many other fields.

After that, in Section 3, we’ll extend our thinking to higher dimensions. I’ll show you how the Fourier transform applies not just to one-dimensional signals, but also to images — and beyond. I’ll even walk you through an example where converting an image to the Fourier domain makes it easy to remove noise.

Finally, in Section 4, we’ll wrap things up with a few remarks and reflections.

So by the end of this lecture, you should not only understand the mathematical structure of the Fourier transform, but also see its real-world value, especially in areas like medical imaging.
Let’s get started with the first section: the derivation of the Fourier transform.

STRICT INSTRUCTIONS:
- Return JSON only. No prose, no markdown, no code fences.
- Output a triple only if both subject and object appear verbatim in SLIDE_TEXT (case-insensitive).
- Predicates must be one of: uses | via | represents | depends_on | measures | produces | reconstructs_with.
- Add modalities ["text"] by default; add "image" only if clearly visible without the text.
- Confidence in [0,1].

OUTPUT:

  "triples": [
    {"s":"<verbatim subject>", "p":"uses|via|represents|depends_on|measures|produces|reconstructs_with",
     "o":"<verbatim object>", "modalities":["text","image"], "confidence":0.0, "evidence":"<short quote from SLIDE_TEXT>"}
  ]
}

User:
SLIDE_TEXT:
So now that we’ve covered the Fourier series — and we’ve seen why changing representations can make problems easier — it’s time to dive into the main topic of today’s lecture: the Fourier transform.

This corresponds to Chapter 4 in the book draft I shared with you. I do plan to revise it soon — polish up some explanations and fix a few typos — and I’ll send you the updated version once it’s ready.

Here’s how we’ll structure today’s lecture:
First, in Section 1, we’ll talk about how the Fourier transform is derived from the Fourier series. This transition is logical and elegant, and it gives us a solid foundation for everything that follows.

Then, in Section 2, we’ll explore some of the most important properties of the Fourier transform. These properties aren’t just mathematical curiosities — they’re practical tools used in signal processing, imaging, and many other fields.

After that, in Section 3, we’ll extend our thinking to higher dimensions. I’ll show you how the Fourier transform applies not just to one-dimensional signals, but also to images — and beyond. I’ll even walk you through an example where converting an image to the Fourier domain makes it easy to remove noise.

Finally, in Section 4, we’ll wrap things up with a few remarks and reflections.

So by the end of this lecture, you should not only understand the mathematical structure of the Fourier transform, but also see its real-world value, especially in areas like medical imaging.
Let’s get started with the first section: the derivation of the Fourier transform.

STRICT INSTRUCTIONS:
- Return JSON only. No prose, no markdown, no code fences.
- Output a triple only if both subject and object appear verbatim in SLIDE_TEXT (case-insensitive).
- Predicates must be one of: uses | via | represents | depends_on | measures | produces | reconstructs_with.
- Add modalities ["text"] by default; add "image" only if clearly visible without the text.
- Confidence in [0,1].

     "o":"<verbatim object>", "modalities":["text","image"], "confidence":0.0, "evidence":"<short quote from SLIDE_TEXT>"}
  ]
}
